Stoats grow a white winter coat to blend in with the snow, but they keep their black tail tip all year round.
Stoats are excellent swimmers and can even climb trees to escape predators or find food.
The stoat's scientific name is Mustela erminea, and it belongs to the same family as weasels, ferrets, and otters.
Stoats are carnivorous and primarily feed on small mammals like rabbits, rodents, and birds.
Female stoats can carry embryos in a state of suspended development, allowing them to delay birth until conditions are favorable for raising their young.
Stoats grow to be weigh between 170 and 350 grams and can reach lengths of up to 30 centimeters, including their tail.
The white winter coat of the stoat is called 'ermine,' and it has been historically prized for use in clothing and royal garments.
A male stoat is called a 'dog,' while a female stoat is called a 'jill,' and their offspring are known as 'kits' or 'pups.'
A group of stoats are called a 'gang' or a 'pack'.
